title: Similar to Neville Brody's 'New Deal'
content:
Hi folks,

I'm looking for a typeface similar to Neville Brody's 'New Deal' which he created for the film _Public Enemies_. However, to my knowledge it was commissioned for the film and isn't available for sale and use elsewhere. It does however, have many characteristics that I'm in love with and it is a perfect fit for a project I have in the works. Any advice on a similar typeface would be much appreciated.

More details on the 'New Deal' typeface: [http://www.aisleone.net/2009/typography/new-deal-typeface-by-neville-brody/](http://web.archive.org/web/20101018072048/http:/www.aisleone.net/2009/typography/new-deal-typeface-by-neville-brody/ "http://www.aisleone.net/2009/typography/new-deal-typeface-by-neville-brody/")

Cheers in advance.
author: Kyle Meyer

comments.content: Back in May 2008 I used [FontStruct](http://web.archive.org/web/20101018072048/http:/typophile.com/wiki/FontStruct) to design something based on the same sources: [WPA Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20101018072048/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/stewf/2485428971/).

Hi Stephen,

Thanks for the link, WPA Gothic is quite similar, and could possibly do the job well. It definitely nails it on the capital Y.

After further examination, it's the capital M in 'New Deal' that really does it for me. I've done some more research and found a number of fonts that fit the bill to a certain extent, but none of them are able to quite capture the modern industrial feel just right:

[Gagarin Anna](http://web.archive.org/web/20101018072048/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/2rebels/gagarin_anna/)  
 [Berber](http://web.archive.org/web/20101018072048/http:/www.letterbox.net.au/store/order_fonts_berber.php)  
 [Liquorstore](http://web.archive.org/web/20101018072048/http:/www.chank.com/font_detail.php?sku=5123)

Perhaps I'm best off modifying one of these appropriately? I've thought about contacting Chank to create a more appropriate capital M.
WPA Gothic is on Fontstruct. Jjust make a new font out of it and change the M.

A good idea, though after playing with it a while, I'm concerned I won't be able to get the x-height correct without creating a rather wide character for the M and subsequently the W. Limitations of Fontstruct unfortunately, but worth a try. Thanks James.
